events.summary: Gioachino Antonio Rossini was born on a leap day, which meant he had a birthday every four years—talk about a great excuse for a party! Growing up in a musical family, it's no surprise he showed a flair for creating tunes early on.
At the tender age of eighteen, Rossini debuted his first opera, a one-act comedy that wowed audiences and earned him a nice pocketful of cash. Who knew making people laugh could also pay the bills?

In a pivotal career move, Rossini strutted his stuff to Naples, where he was officially engaged to churn out operas and manage theaters. It was like being hired as the star chef in a world-class restaurant!

events.event: Creation of Il barbiere di Siviglia
events.summary: Despite a rocky start with a botched premiere, Rossini's adaptation of The Barber of Seville soon became a perpetual favorite, proving that a bad opening night is just a warm-up act for a legendary career.

Rossini became a hot commodity when he signed a contract with the Paris Opera. He basically became the go-to guy for lavish productions and elegant soirées, proving that opera was as much about the social scene as it was about the music.

After a brief whirlwind of creativity, Rossini decided to hang up his composing hat at fifty, leaving behind a legacy with a dramatic flair. His last opera was a riveting piece, fittingly tied to his love of grand gestures, showcasing an exit that rivaled even the most elaborate of operatic finales.

In his later years, Rossini found joy in hosting vibrant musical salons that drew the crème de la crème of the artistic world. Guests marveled at his witty compositions, proving that even in retirement, he could throw the best parties in town.

Rossini made a grand artistic statement with his Petite messe solennelle, reminding everyone that even after stepping back from the limelight, his flair for drama and innovation was still very much alive!

In a romantic twist of fate, Rossini married his beloved Colbran in a small church, showcasing that even amidst opera and insurrection, love finds a way. They broke their journey at Bologna for this momentous occasion, making it clear that dinner plans were not the only things on the menu!

Upon arriving in Vienna, Rossini was greeted with such fervor that it was described as 'Rossini fever'—a remarkable reception that could rival modern fan conventions. His music was so adored that even Beethoven's assistant suggested the audience was caught in an 'idolatrous orgy' of applause!

The premiere of Semiramide saw Colbran in the leading role, but unfortunately, her voice wasn't ready for the grand finale—talk about a plot twist! Despite the drama, the opera became a staple of the repertoire and marked a sparkling end note to Rossini's Italian career.

Rossini landed in London, where he was welcomed by King George IV—though it seems the composer had reached a point in his life where royal greetings were no longer the high point. After signing lucrative contracts, he still felt more aligned with French culture and vowed never to let British cuisine ruin his appetite again!

Rossini composed Il viaggio a Reims, celebrating Charles X's coronation with a grand ‘operatic entertainment.’ Too bad he didn't stick around for its success—because he only permitted a mere four performances! It was his way of keeping things exclusive, like a VIP club for opera enthusiasts.

In a bittersweet twist, Rossini experienced the profound loss of his mother, Anna. With her passing, he entered a new chapter that didn't just shake emotional foundations but also his personal life, making his wife the only woman left at home to claim his attention—poor Colbran!

Rossini wrote Le comte Ory, creating his only French-language comic opera. The catch? He reused music from Il viaggio a Reims which, let’s say, made things a tad complicated for his librettists. It was a musical puzzle that somehow paid off when it became a smash hit!

With the release of Guillaume Tell, Rossini unleashed a grand opera that had the public and orchestra celebrating outside his window. Even the critics agreed that it was exquisite, zeroing in on the classic Rossini magic while also prompting the awkward discussion about whether God helped with the middle act—who could blame them for asking?

In a plot twist that would shock the audience, Rossini decided to retire from opera after Guillaume Tell. At just thirty-seven, he was likened to Shakespeare, leaving performers and composers puzzled by the mystery of his sudden disappearance from the stage—perhaps he simply needed a snack and a nap!

After years of artistic separation from Colbran, Rossini ultimately tied the knot with Olympe Pélissier, a dramatic turn indeed! This occasion concluded an era and opened a new chapter filled with gourmet delights and much less opera, because who needs that when you have love?
Rossini tied the knot with his beloved Pélissier in Bologna, proving that even a music genius can find time for romance amidst the chaos of his career.
In the wake of the 1848 revolutions, Rossini fled Bologna like a startled pigeon, setting up shop in Florence and claiming it as his musical HQ until 1855.
After realizing that his health was in worse shape than a poorly tuned piano, Rossini and his wife packed their bags for Paris, where he was once again about to experience a second act in life.
Rossini kicked off his infamous Saturday evening salons, where the musical elite gathered like moths to a flame, proving his social life was just as extravagant as his operas.
He dedicated the song cycle Musique anodine to his wife, capturing the essence of gratitude with a sprinkle of comedic irony – is there a better way to say 'I love you' than with music?

events.event: First Performance of Petite messe solennelle
events.summary: Rossini decided to unveil one of his few public pieces, the Petite messe solennelle, proving that he hadn't entirely retired but was just waiting for the right moment.
In recognition of his contributions, Napoleon III made Rossini a grand officer of the Legion of Honour – apparently, musical genius really does come with perks!

After a remarkable life filled with music, salons, and a touch of celebrity, Rossini passed away, leaving behind a legacy that would ensure his music never went out of style, much like a timeless fashion.

In a spectacular rising star moment, Rossini premiered his opera Tancredi in Venice, instantly elevating him to the ranks of the top opera composers. The audience was so amazed they probably considered him the Mozart of their time, minus the wigs!

Barely a few months after Tancredi, Rossini unleashed another hit with L'italiana in Algeri. The comic opera was so entertaining that it became the talk of the town, proving that Rossini could not only bring the drama but also the laughs!

Rossini snagged a seven-year contract in Naples with Theatre manager Domenico Barbaja, marking his royal entry into the opera scene. It was like a season ticket to creativity, giving him the freedom to flex his musical muscles!

With Otello, Rossini not only showed off his mastery over dramatic composition but also revealed his talent for jolly vocal lines, leaving the audience wondering if they were at a poetry slam or an opera house!

Rossini's Il barbiere di Siviglia premiered, leaving everyone in stitches with Figaro's shenanigans. This opera became so popular that it practically received its own VIP backstage pass in the opera world!

Even when he took a break from making audiences laugh, Rossini composed the Stabat Mater, making it a sacred work that was about as serious as a musical piece could get, but with enough flair for the opera alum!

Rossini took the reins as director of the Théâtre-Italien in Paris. This gig allowed him to bring Italian opera glamour to the French capital, proving that he could indeed get a crowd on their feet in any city!

Rossini celebrated his love for drama and folk music with the premiere of Guillaume Tell, which became such a hit that, just like a great party, it kept getting invited back for encores – 500 performances later, he still had a fan club!

In his twilight years, Rossini humorously churned out a collection called Péchés de vieillesse (Sins of Old Age), proving that even the greatest can't resist a bit of joviality and nostalgia, leaving plenty of chuckles in his wake!

And then came the Petite messe solennelle, a piece that somehow decided it was too big for the 'petite' label and included a mix of jolly melodies and heartfelt moments, truly a celebration of Rossini's unique style!

Rossini composed his first opera at a tender age, showcasing his prodigious talent early on. It was a sign that he was not just a little boy singing in the shower, but rather someone destined for the grand stages!

His opera 'Tancredi' premiered, finally allowing him to break free from the clutches of mere mortal existence and step into the world of operatic fame. The applause must have been deafening, or maybe just a lot of over-the-top 'bravos'!
Rossini tied the knot with the famous soprano Isabella Colbran, proving that marrying your muse can definitely spark some fire in your compositions—if not your kitchen!

He reached the zenith of his career with operas like 'Il barbiere di Siviglia' which became an instant hit. People were swooning over the melodies, while Rossini probably had to swat away flocks of admirers!

In a plot twist that startled everyone, Rossini announced his retirement from composing operas before he really ran out of ideas, leaving fans wondering if he had taken a permanent vacation from creativity!

Despite retiring, Rossini couldn't resist the call of the piano and returned to the drawing board to write his famous 'Stabat Mater', proving that once a composer, always a composer. Who could resist the urge to serenade, after all?
At a tender age, Rossini composed his first opera and shocked the audience, not with the music but with the amount of arias he packed into one evening.
This comedic masterpiece premiered to thunderous applause, proving that sometimes laughter is indeed the best medicine—even if it comes wrapped in an opera.
After a prolific career, Rossini decided that composing operas was taxing, opting instead for leisurely meals and exquisite desserts—an art form in itself.
In a surprising twist, Rossini revealed his final composition in a grand performance, leaving his audience in awe, and perhaps a little curious about what he was cooking up next.

compositions.title: Canone scherzoso a quattro soprani democratici
Duet for Cello and Double Bass in D major
Farò come colui che piange e dice
Per la collezione della Biblioteca Reale di Berlino
